title: 111_hr1247
content: The Act may be cited as the "Protecting Tenants at Foreclosure Act of 2009" and addresses the effect of foreclosure on existing tenancy. The "Protecting Tenants at Foreclosure Act of 2009" requires any successor in interest after a foreclosure on a dwelling to provide a 90-day notice to vacate to tenants and honor existing leases, except in certain circumstances. The "Protecting Tenants at Foreclosure Act of 2009" mandates a 90-day notice for tenants to vacate after a foreclosure, with exceptions for subsidized tenancies or longer time periods under local laws. A lease or tenancy is valid if the mortgagor is not the tenant and the agreement was made at arm's length. The lease or tenancy must be the result of an arms-length transaction and require rent not substantially below fair market value. Effect of foreclosure on Section 8 tenancies. Amendment to section 8(o) of the United States Housing Act of 1937 regarding the treatment of property vacancy before sale by an owner who is an immediate successor in interest pursuant to foreclosure. Amendment to section 8(o) of the United States Housing Act of 1937 requires that in case of foreclosure on residential real property, the immediate successor in interest must assume the lease and housing assistance payments contract of the prior owner. The Amendment to section 8(o) of the United States Housing Act of 1937 mandates that the immediate successor in interest must take over the lease and housing assistance payments after foreclosure. If the successor fails to comply, the agency can use funds to pay for utilities on behalf of the family without prior notification to the owner. The Amendment to section 8(o) of the United States Housing Act of 1937 requires the immediate successor in interest to take over the lease and housing assistance payments after foreclosure. Notification is not needed if the unit becomes uninhabitable due to service termination. The public housing agency must notify the owner promptly after making payments for moving costs. State or local laws providing longer time periods or additional tenant protections are not affected.
